newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Sudan awards oil deal to four-party consortium.
newsitem.headline: Sudan awards oil deal to four-party consortium.

text.p: A consortium of four state-owned oil companies have signed a deal with the Sudanese government to look for oil in the Muglad Basin of Sudan, Malaysia's national oil and gas firm Petronas said on Sunday.
The agreement, valid for 25 years, was signed in Khartoum on Saturday and covers an area of 49,393 sq km in the Muglad Basin, Petronas, one of the joint venture partners, said in a statement.
The three other partners are Sudan's national oil company Sudapet, State Petroleum Corp -- a subsidiary of Canada's Arakis Energy Corp -- and China National Petroleum Corp.
Sudapet has a five percent stake, Canada's State Petroleum 25 percent, Petronas 30 percent, and China National Petroleum Corp 40 percent.

The joint-venture will involve integrated exploration, development and production of oil from Blocks 1,2 and 4 on the Muglad Basin, which have total proven reserves of 560 million barrels, Petronas said.
It said under the agreement, the joint-venture partners will also construct, own and operate a 1,500-km export pipeline from the oil fields to Port Sudan.
The first shipment of oil for export is expected in January 2000, Petronas said.
